case_vignette: A 14-year-old boy who has been otherwise healthy presents to his doctor complaining of feeling easily winded and light-headed at basketball practice. He has never felt this way before and is frustrated because he is good enough to make varsity this year. He denies smoking, alcohol, or recreational drug use. His mother is very worried because her oldest son and brother had both died suddenly while playing sports despite being otherwise healthy. The transthoracic echocardiogram confirms the suspected diagnosis, which demonstrates a preserved ejection fraction and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. The patient is advised that he will need to stay hydrated and avoid intense exercise, and he will likely need an ICD due to his family history.
question: Which  physical exam findings is consistent with this patient’s most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Cardiovascular System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling easily winded and light-headed at basketball practice.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've never felt this way before; it just started recently.
Do you have any medical conditions or take any medications?
No, I've been otherwise healthy and I don't take any medications.
Do you have a family history of heart problems?
Yes, my oldest brother and my uncle both died suddenly while playing sports even though they were healthy.

Based on your symptoms and family history, it's important for you to see a doctor as soon as possible. These symptoms and family history may be indicative of a serious heart condition. I recommend getting evaluated by a healthcare professional promptly.
